So methinks . And what of that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Will you therefore be pleased, as you are worthy gentlemen, and blessed with plenty —
This is courtly!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Out of your abundant store, towards my relief in extreme necessity, to furnish me with a small parcel of money — five or six pieces, or ten, if you can presently spare it.
Stand off. Draw.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I have spoiled all; and know not how to beg otherwise.
Here's a new way of begging!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Quite run out of my instructions.
Some highway thief of my conscience, that forgets he is weaponless.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Only to make you merry, gentlemen, at my unskilfulness in my new trade. I have been another man i' my days. So I kiss your hands. Exit.
With your heels do you?
It had been good to have apprehended the rakeshame. There is some mystery in his rags. But let him go.

div.stage: Enter Oliver, putting up his sword.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You found your legs in time, I had made you halt for something else.
Master Oliver, well returned; what's the matter, sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why, sir, a counterfeit lame rogue begged of me; but in such language, the high sheriff's son of the shire could not have spoke better; nor to have borrowed a greater sum. (He asked me if I could spare him ten or twenty pound.) I switched him, his cudgel was up. I drew, and into the wood he scaped me, as nimbly — but first he told me, I should hear from him by a gentleman, to require satisfaction of me.
We had such another begged of us. The court goes a-begging , I think.
Dropped through the clouds, I think; more lucifers travailing to hell, that beg by the way. Met you no news of your kinswoman, mistress Amie?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: No. What's the matter with her? Goes her marriage forwards with young, master talboy? I hastened my journey from London to be at the wedding.

Was to ha' been yesterday morning; all things in readiness prepared for it. But the bride, stolen by your father's clerk, is slipped away. We were in quest of 'em, and so are twenty more, several ways.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Such young wenches will have their own ways in their own loves, what matches soever their guardians make for 'em. And I hope my father will not follow the law so close to hang his clerk for stealing his ward with her own consent. It may breed such a grudge, may cause some clerks to hang their masters, that have 'em of the hip of injustice. Besides, Martin (Though he be his servant) is a gentleman. But, indeed, the miserablest rascal! He will grudge her meat when he has her.

Your father is exceedingly troubled at their
escape. I wish that you may qualify him with your reasons.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But what says talboy to the matter, the bridegroom, that should ha' been?
Marry he says little to the purpose; but cries outright.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I like him well for that: he holds his humour. A miserable wretch too, though rich. I ha' known him cry when he has lost but three shillings at mumchance. But, gentlemen, keep on your way to comfort my father. I know some of his man's private haunts about the country here, which I will search immediately.
We will accompany you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: No, by no means: that will be too public.
Do your pleasure. Exit 1.2.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
My pleasure, and all the search that I intend, is, by hovering here, to take a review of a brace of the handsomest beggar-braches that ever graced a ditch or a hedge side. I passed by 'em in haste, but something so possesses me, that I must — what the devil must I? A beggar? Why, beggars are flesh and blood; and rags are no diseases. Their lice are no French fleas. And there is much wholesomer flesh under country dirt, than city painting: and less danger in dirt and rags, than in ceruse and satin. I durst not take a touch at London, both for the present cost, and fear of an after-reckoning. But Oliver, dost thou speak like a gentleman? fear price or pox, ha? Marry do I sir: nor can beggar-sport be inexcusable in a young country gentleman, short of means, for another respect, a principal one indeed; to avoid the
punishment or charge of bastardy: there's no commuting with them; or keeping of children for them. The poor whores, rather than part with their own, or want children at all, will steal other folks, to travel with, and move compassion. He feeds a beggar-wench well that fills her belly with young bones. And these reasons considered, good master Oliver — 'slid yonder they are at peep. And now sitten down as waiting for my purpose. Ent. Vinc.heart here's another delay. I must shift him. Dost hear honest poor fellow? I prithee go back presently: and at the hill foot (Here's sixpence for thy pains) thou shalt find a footman with a horse in his hand. Bid him wait there. His master will come presently, say.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Sir, I have a business of another nature to you. Which (As I presume you are a gentleman of right noble spirit and resolution) you will receive without offence; and in that temper as most properly appertains to the most heroic natures.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Thy language makes me wonder at thy person. What's the matter with thee? quickly.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You may be pleased to call to mind a late affront, which, in your heat of passion, you gave a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What, such a one as thou art, was he?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: True noble sir. Who could no less in honour, then direct me, his chosen friend, unto you, with the length of his sword, or to take the length of yours. The place, if you please, the ground whereon you parted; the hour, seven the next morning: or, if you like not these, in part, or all, to make your own appointments.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: The bravest method in beggars, that ever was discovered! I would be upon the bones of this rogue now, but for crossing my other design, which fires me. I must therefore be rid of him on any terms. Let his own appointments stand. Tell him I'll meet him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You shall most nobly engage his life to serve you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You'll be his second, will you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: To do you further service, sir, I have undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I'll send a beadle shall undertake you both.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your mirth becomes the bravery of your mind and dauntless spirit. So takes his leave your servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I think, as my friend said, the court goes a-begging indeed. But I must not lose my beggar-wenches. Enter Rachel and Meriel.o here they come. They are delicately skinned and limbed. There, there, I saw above the ham as the wind blew. Now they spy me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you look upon us with the favour of a gentleman. We are in a present distress, and utterly unacquainted in these parts; and therefore forced by the calamity of our misfortune, to implore the courtesy, or rather charity, of those to whom we are strangers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Very fine, this!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Be therefore pleased, right noble sir, not only valuing us by our outward habits, which cannot but appear loathsome or despicable unto you, but as we are forlorn Christians; and, in that estimation, be compassionately moved to cast a handful or two of your silver, or a few of your golden pieces
unto us, to furnish us with linen, and some decent habiliments —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: They beg as high as the man-beggar I met withal! sure the beggars are all mad today, or bewitched into a language they understand not. The spirits of some decayed gentry talk in 'em sure.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: May we expect a gracious answer from you sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And that as you can wish our virgin prayers to be propitious for you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That you never be denied a suit by any mistress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, that the fairest may be ambitious to place their favours on you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That your virtue and valour may lead you to the most honourable actions; and that the love of all exquisite ladies may arm you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And that, when you please to take a wife, may honour, beauty, and wealth, contend to endow her most with.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And that with her you have a long and prosperous life.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A fair and fortunate posterity.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: This exceeds all that ever I heard, and strikes me into wonder. Pray tell me how long have you been beggars; or how chanced you to be so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: By influence of our stars, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We were born to no better fortune.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: How came you to talk thus, and so much above the beggar's dialect?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Our speech came naturally to us, and we ever loved to learn by wrote as well as we could.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And to be ambitious above the vulgar, to
ask more than common alms, whate'er men please to give us.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sure some well disposed gentleman, as myself, got these wenches. They are too well grown to be mine own, and I cannot be incestuous with 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pray sir your noble bounty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What a tempting lip that little rogue moves there! and what an enticing eye the 'Tother. I know not which to begin with. What's this a flea upon thy bosom?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is it not a straw coloured one, sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: O what a provoking skin is there! that very touch inflames me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, are you moved in charity towards us yet?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Moved? I am moved. No flesh and blood more moved.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then pray sir your benevolence.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Benevolence? which shall I be benevolent to; or which first? I am puzzled in the choice. Would some sworn brother of mine were here to draw a cut with me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: First let me tell you, damsels, I am bound by a strong vow to kiss all of the woman sex I meet this morning.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Beggars and all sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: All, all. Let not your coyness cross a gentleman's vow, I beseech you —Kiss.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You will tell now.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Tell quoth 'a! I could tell a thousand on those lips — and as many upon those. What life restoring breathes they have! Milk from the cow steams not so sweetly. I must lay one of 'em aboard; both if my tackling hold.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mer. Sir. Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But how to bargain, now, will be the doubt. They that beg so high as by the handfuls, may expect for price above the rate of good men's wives.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Now, will you, sir, be pleased?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: With all my heart, sweetheart. And I am glad thou knowest my mind. Here is twelvepence a piece for you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Me. We thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: That's but in earnest. I'll jest away the rest with ye. Look here — all this. Come, you know my meaning. Dost thou look about thee, sweet little one? I like thy care. There's nobody coming. But we'll get behind these bushes. I know you keep each others counsels — must you be drawn to't? Then I'll pull. Come away —

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Me. Ah ah —

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Let's beat his brains out.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Come leave your squealing.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: O you hurt my hand.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Or cut the lechers throat.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Would you be hanged? Stand back. Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You shall not pull us so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O do not hurt 'em, master.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Hurt 'em? I meant 'em but too well. Shall I be so prevented?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: They be but young and simple. And if they have offended, let not your worships own hands drag 'em to the law, or carry 'em to punishment. Correct 'em not yourself. It is the beadle's office.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Do you talk shake-rag: heart yond's more
of 'em. I shall be beggar-mauled if I stay. Thou sayest right, honest fellow, there's a tester for thee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: He is prevented, and ashamed of his purpose.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Nor were we to take notice of his purpose more than to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: True, politic Springlove, 'twas better his own fear quit us of him, than our force.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Look you here, gentlemen, twelvepence a piece

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Besides fair offers and large promises. What ha' you got today, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: More than (As we are gentlemen) we would have taken.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yet we put it up in your service.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mer. Ha ha ha. Switches and kicks. Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Talk not here of your gettings. We must quit this quarter. The eager gentleman's repulse may arm and return him with revenge upon us. We must therefore leap hedge and ditch now; through the briers and mires, till we scape out of this liberty, to our next rendezvous; where we shall meet the crew, and then, hay toss and laugh all night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: As we did last night.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hold out, Meriel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Lead on, brave general. To Spr.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What shall we do? They are in heart still. Shall we go on?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: There's no flinching back, you see.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Besides, if you beg no better than you begin, in this lofty fashion, you cannot scape the jail, or the whip, long.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: To tell you true, 'tis not the least of my purpose, to work means for our discovery, to be released out of our trade.

div.stage: Enter Martin and Amy in poor habits.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Stay, here come more passengers. Single yourselves again, and fall to your calling discreetly.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I'll single no more. If you'll beg in full cry I am for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I that will be fine; let's charm all together.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Stay first and list a little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be of good cheer, sweetheart, we have scaped hitherto: and I believe that all the search is now retired, and we may safely pass forwards.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I should be safe with thee. But that's a most lying proverb, that says, where love is, there's no lack. I am faint, and cannot travail further without meat; and if you loved me, you would get me some.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We'll venture at the next village to call for some. The best is, we want no money.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We shall be taken then, I fear. I'll rather pine to death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be not so fearful. Who can know us in these clownish habits?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Our clothes, indeed, are poor enough to beg with. Would I could beg, so it were of strangers that could not know me, rather than buy of those that would betray us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yonder be some that can teach us.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: These are the young couple of runaway lovers disguised, that the country is so laid for. Observe and follow now. Now the lord to come with ye, good loving master and mistress, your blessed charity to the poor, lame and sick, weak and comfortless, that will night and day —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you. Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace, and let me alone. Good young master and mistress, a little comfort amongst us all, and to bless you where'er you go, and

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you. Duly and truly —

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Pray do not use me thus. Now sweet young master and mistress, to look upon your poor, that have no relief or succour, no bread to put in our heads.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Wouldst thou put bread in thy brains?

div.l: No lands or livings.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No house nor home; nor covering from the cold; no health, no help but your sweet charity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No bands or shirts but lousy on our backs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No smocks or petticoats to hide our scratches.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No shoes to our legs, or hose to our feet.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No skin to our flesh, nor flesh to our bones shortly.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: If we follow the devil that taught us to beg.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I'll run away from you if you beg a stroke more. Good worshipful master and mistress —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good friend forbear. Here is no master or mistress. We are poor folks. Thou seest no worship upon our backs, I am sure. And for within, we want as much as you, and would as willingly beg, if we knew how as well.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Alack for pity. You may have enough. And what I have is yours, if you'll accept it. 'tis wholesome food from a good gentleman's gate — alas good mistress — much good do your heart. How savourly she feeds!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What do you mean; to poison yourself?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Do you show love in grudging me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if you think it hurts you not, fall too. I'll not beguile you. And here, mine host, something towards your reckoning.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: This beggar is an angel sure!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Nothing by way of bargain, gentle master. 'tis against order, and will never thrive. But pray, sir, your reward in charity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here then in charity. This fellow would never make a clerk.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What! all this, master?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: What is it? Let me see't.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: 'Tis a whole silver threepence, mistress.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: For shame, ingrateful miser. Here friend, a golden crown for thee.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Bountiful goodness! Gold? If I thought a dear year were coming, I would take a farm now.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I have robbed thy partners of their shares too. There's a crown more for them.
Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What have you done? less would have served. And your bounty will betray us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Fie on your wretched policy.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
No, no good master. I knew you all this while, and my sweet mistress too. And now I'll tell you. The search is every way; the country all laid for you. 'tis well you stayed here. Your habits, were they but a little nearer our fashion, would secure you with us. But are you married, master and mistress? Are you joined in matrimony? In heart I know you are. And I will (If it please you) for your great bounty, bring you to a curate, that
lacks no licence, nor has any living to lose, that shall put you together.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou art a heavenly beggar!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But he is so scrupulous, and severely precise, that unless you, mistress, will affirm that you are with child by the gentleman; or that you have, at least, cleft or slept together (As he calls it) he will not marry you. But if you have lyen together, then 'tis a case of necessity, and he holds himself bound to do it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You may say you have.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I would not have it so, nor make that lie against myself for all the world.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: That I like well, and her exceedingly.Aside
I'll do my best for you however.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll do for thee, that — thou shalt never beg more.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That cannot be purchased scarce for the price of your mistress. Will you walk, master? — we use no compliments.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: By enforced matches wards are not set free
So oft, as sold into captivity:
Which made me, fearless, fly from one I hate,
Into the hazard of a harder fate.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter talboy. Oliver. With riding switches.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: She's gone. Amie is gone. Ay me she's gone, and has me left of joy bereft, to make my moan. O me, Amie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What the devil ails the fellow trow? why! why master talboy; my cousin talboy that shouldst ha' been, art not ashamed to cry at this growth? and for a thing that's better lost than found; a wench?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Cry! who cries? do I cry; or look with a crying countenance? I scorn it; and scorn to think on her, but in just anger.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: So, this is brave now, if 'twould hold.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: Nay it shall hold. And so let her go, for a scurvy what d'ye call't; I know not what bad enough to call her. — but something of mine goes with her I am sure. She has cost me in gloves, ribbons, scarves, rings, and such like things, more than I am able to speak of at this time — oh.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Because thou canst not speak for crying. Fie master talboy, again?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I scorn it again, and any man that says I cry, or will cry again and let her go again; and what she has of mine let her keep, and hang herself, and the rogue that's with her. I have enough; and am heir of a well-known estate, and that she knows — and therefore that she should sleight me, and run away with a wages-fellow, that is but a petty clerk and a servingman. There's the vexation of it — o there's the grief, and the vexation of it — o —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Now he will cry his eyes out! You sir. This life have I had with you all our long journey; which now is at an end here. This is master oldrents house, where perhaps we shall find old hearty, the uncle of that rogue Martin, that is run away with your sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I 'tis too true, too true, too true. You need not put me in mind on't — o — oh —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Hold your peace and mind me. Leave your bawling, for fear I give you correction. This is the house I say, where it is most likely we shall hear of your mistress and her companion. Make up your face quickly. Here comes one of the servants, I suppose. Enter Randall.shame not yourself for ever, and me for company. Come, be confident.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: As confident as yourself or any man — but my poor heart feels what lies here. Here. I here it is, oh —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good morrow, friend. This is squire oldrents house, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Pray take it not, sir, before it be to be let. It has been my masters, and his ancestors in that name, above these three hundred years, as our house chronicle doth notify; and not yet to be let. But as a friend, or stranger, in guestwise, you are welcome to it; as all other gentlemen are, far and near, to my good master, as you will find anon when you see him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Thou speak'st wittily and honestly. But I prithee, good friend, let our nags be set up: they are tied up at the post. You belong to the stable, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Not so much, as the stable belongs to me, sir. I pass through many offices of the house, sir. I am the running Bayley of it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: We have rid hard, hoping to find the squire at home at this early time in the morning.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You are deceived in that, sir. He has been out these four hours. He is no snail, sir. You do not know him, I perceive, since he has been new moulded. But I'll tell you, because you are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Our horses, good friend.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: My master is an ancient gentleman, and a great housekeeper; and prayed for by all the poor in the country. He keeps a guesthouse for all beggars, far and near, costs him a hundred a year, at least; and is as well beloved among the Rich. But, of late, he fell into a great melancholy, upon what, I know not: for he had then more cause to be merry than he has now. Take that by the way.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But good fiend, our horses.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: For he had two daughters, that knew well to order a house, and give entertainment to gentlemen. They were his house-doves. But now they are flown; and no man knows how, why, or whither.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: My dove is flown too. O —

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Was she your daughter, sir? She was a young one then, by the beard you wear.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: What she was, she was, d'ye see. I scorn to think on her — but I do — oh.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace, or feign some mirth, if you can.

sp.speaker: Sing. Tal.
sp.p:
Let her go, let her go. I care not if I
have her, I have her or no. Ha ha ha — o my heart will break — o —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray think of our horses, sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: This is right my master. When he had his daughters he was sad; and now they are gone, he is the merriest man alive. Up at five o'clock in the morning, and out till dinnertime. Out again at afternoon, and so till suppertime. Skise out this away, and skise out that away. (He's no snail I assure you.) And tantivy all the country over, where hunting, hawking, or any sport is to be made, or good fellowship to be had; and so merry upon all occasions, that you would even bless yourself, if it were possible.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Our horses, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And we, his servants, live as merrily under him; and do all thrive. I myself was but a silly lad when I came first, a poor turnspit boy. Gentlemen kept no whirling jacks then, to cozen poor people of meat. And I have now, without boast, 40. l. in my purse, and am the youngest of half a score in the house, none younger than myself but one; and he is the steward over all; his name is master Springlove (Bless him where ere he is) he has a world of means: and we, the underlings, get well the better by him; besides the rewards many gentlemen give us, that fare well, and lodge here sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: O! we shall not forget you, friend, if you remember our horses, before they take harm.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: No hurt, I warrant you: there's a lad walking them.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Is not your master coming, think you?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: He will not be long a coming. He's no snail, as I told you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You told me so, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But of all the gentlemen, that toss up the ball, yea and the sack too, commend me to old master hearty; a decayed gentleman; lives most upon his own mirth, and my master's means, and much good do him with it: he is the finest companion of all: he does so hold my master up with storeys, and songs, and catches, and tother cup of sack, and such tricks and jigs, you would admire — he is with him now.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: That hearty is Martin's uncle. I am glad he is here. Bear up talboy. Now, friend, pray let me ask you a question. — prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, marry I dare not. Your yawdes may take cold, and never be good after it. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I thought I should never have been rid of him. But no sooner desired to stay, but he is gone. A pretty humour!

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my master will be here e'en now, doubt not: for he is no snail, as I told you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: No snail's a great word with him. Prithee talboy bear up. Enter usherhere comes another grey fellow.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Do you stand in the porch, gentlemen? the house is open to you. Pray enter the hall. I am the usher of it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: In good time, sir. We shall be bold here, then, to attend your masters coming.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: And he's upon coming; and when he comes he comes apace. He is no snail, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I was told so before, sir. No snail! sure 'tis
the word of the house, and as ancient as the family.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: This gentleman looks sadly, methinks .

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Who I? not I. Pray pardon my looks for that. But my heart feels what's what. Ay me —

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Pray walk to the buttery, gentlemen. My office leads you thither.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Thanks, good master usher.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: I have been usher these twenty years, sir. And have got well by my place, for using strangers respectfully.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He has given the hint too.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Something has come in by the by, besides standing wages, which is ever duly paid (Thank a good master, and an honest steward) heaven bless 'em. We all thrive under'em . Enter Butler with glasses and a napkin.o here comes the butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You are welcome, gentlemen. Please ye draw nearer my office, and take a morning drink in a cup of sack, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: In what please you, sir. We cannot deny the courtesy of the house, in the master's absence.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: He'll come apace when he comes. He's no snail, sir. Going.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Still 'tis the house-word. And all the servants wear livery-beards.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Or perhaps you had rather drink whitewine and sugar. Please yourselves, gentlemen; here you may taste all liquours. No gentleman's house in all this county, or the next, so well stored (— make us thankful for it.) And my master, for his hospitality to gentlemen, his charity to the poor, and his bounty to his servants, has not his peer in the
kingdom (— make us thankful for it.) And 'tis as fortunate a house for servants, as ever was built upon faery-ground. I myself, that have served here, man, and boy, these four and forty years, have gotten together (Besides something, more than I will speak of, distributed among my poor kindred) by my wages, my vails at Christmas, and otherwise, together with my rewards of kind gentlemen, that have found courteous entertainment here. —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: There he is too.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Have, I say, gotten together (Though in a dangerous time I speak it) a brace of hundred pounds — make me thankful for it. And for losses, I have had none. I have been butler these two and thirty years, and never lost the value of a silver spoon, nor ever broke a glass — make me thankful for it. White wine and sugar, say you sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Please yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: This gentleman speaks not. Or had you rather take a drink of brown ale with a toast, or march beer with sugar and nutmeg? or had you rather drink without sugar?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good sir, a cup of your household-beer. Exit. But.I fear he will draw down to that at last.

div.stage: Enter Butler with a silver can of sack.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Here, gentlemen, is a cup of my masters small beer: but it is good old canary, I assure you. And here's to your welcome.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
And welcome the cook says, gentlemen. Brother Butler, lay a napkin, I'll fetch a cut of the sirloin to strengthen your patience till my master
comes, who will not now be long, for he's no snail, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I have often heard so. And here's to you, master cook — prithee speak, master talboy, or force one laugh more, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, the cook drinks to you. To Talb.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He is in the same livory-beard too.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: But he is the oldest cook, and of the ancientest house, and the best for housekeeping, in this county, or the next. And though the master of it write but squire, I know no lord like him. Enter chaplain.and now he's come. Here comes the word before him. The parson has ever the best stomach. I'll dish away presently.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Is our master come, sir dominae?

sp.speaker: Chaplain
sp.p: Est ad manum. Non est ille testudo.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He has the word too in Latin. Now bear up talboy.

sp.speaker: Chaplain
sp.p: Give me a preparative of sack. It is a gentle preparative before meat. And so a gentle touch of it to you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: It is a gentle offer, sir; and as gently to be taken.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: About with it, my lads. And this is as it should be. — not till my turn, sir, I. Though, I confess, I have had but three morning-draughts today.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yet it appears you were abroad betimes, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I am no snail, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: So your men told us, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: But where be my catchers? Come, a round. And so let us drink.

div.stage: The catch sung. And they drink about. The singers are all graybeards.
div.l: A round, a round, a round, boys, a round.
Let mirth fly aloft, and sorrow be drowned.
Old sack, and old songs, and a merry old crew,
Can charm away cares when the ground looks blue.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well said old hearty. And, gentlemen, welcome.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: Ah —He sighs.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O mine ears! What was that, a sigh? And in my house? Look: has it not split my walls? If not, make vent for it: let it out: I shall be stifled else. Exit. Chap.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He hopes your pardon, sir: his cause considered.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Cause? Can there be cause for sighing.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He ▪ has lost his mistress, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ha ha ha. Is that a cause? Do you hear me complain the loss of my two daughters?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: They are not lost, I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: No more can be his mistress. No woman can be lost. They may be mislaid a little: but found again, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ah —Sigh.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ods my life! He sighs again: and means to blow me out of my house. To horse again. Here's no dwelling for me. Or stay: I'll cure him, if I can. Give him more sack, to drown his suspirations.

div.stage: While oldrents and talboy drink. Oliver takes hearty aside.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, I am chiefly to inform you of the disaster.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: May it concern me?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Your nephew Martin has stolen my father's ward, that gentleman's bride that should have been.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis most true —He gives hearty a letter.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Another glass of sack. This gentleman brings good news.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, if you can prevent his danger —

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Hang all preventions. Let 'em have their destiny.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Sir, I should have had her, 'tis true — but she is gone, d'ye see? And let her go. To oldrents.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well said. He mends now.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I am glad I am rid of her (D'ye see) before I had more to do with her —

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: He mends apace.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: For should I have married her before she had run away, d'ye see: and that she had run away (D'ye see) after she had been married to me (D'ye see.) Than I had been a married man without a wife (D'ye see.) Where now she being run away before I am married (D'ye see) I am no more married to her, d'ye see, than she to me, d'ye see. And so long as I am none of hers (D'ye see) nor she none of mine (D'ye see) I ought to care as little for her, now she is run away (D'ye see) as if she had stayed with me, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why this is excellent! Come hither hearty.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I perceive it now; and the reason of it; and
how, by consequence (D'ye see) I ought not to look any further after her. Cries.but that she should respect a poor base fellow, a clerk at the most, and a servingman at best, before me, that am a rich man, at the worst; and a gentleman, at least, makes me — I know not what to say —

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Worse than ever 'twas! Now he cries outright.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I know not what to say — what to say — o —

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Then I do, sir. The poor base fellow, that you speak of, is my nephew: as good a gentleman as yourself. I understand the business by your friend here.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: You shall cry no mercy, nor any thing else here, sir; nor for any thing, here, sir. This is no place to cry in: nor for any business. You, sir, that come on business —To Ol.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: It shall be none, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: My house is for no business; but the belly-business. You find not me so uncivil, sir, as to ask you from whence you came; who you are; or what's your business. I ask you no question. And can you be so discourteous, as to tell me, or my friend, any thing like business. If you come to be merry with me, you are welcome. If you have any business, forget it: you forget where you are else. And so to dinner.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Sir, I pray let me only prevail with you but to read this.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Spoil my stomach now, and I'll not eat this fortnight. He reads aside.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: While he reads, let me tell you, sir. That my nephew Martin has stolen that gentleman's mistress, it seems, is true. But I protest, as I am a gentleman, I know nothing of the matter; nor where he or she is. But, as I am the foresaid gentleman, I am glad on't with all my heart. Ha, my boy Mat. Thou shall restore our house.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Let him not hear, to grieve him, sir.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Grieve him? What should he do with her; teach their children to cry?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: But I do hear you though; and I scorn to cry, as much as you, d'ye see, or your nephew either, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Now thou art a brave fellow. So, so, hold up thy head, and thou shalt have a wife, and a fine thing.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Hang a wife; and pax of your fine thing (D'ye see) I scorn your fopperies, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: And I do hear thee, my boy; and rejoice in thy conversion. If thou canst but hold now.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Yes, I can hold, sir. And I hold well with your sack. I could live and die with it, as I am true talboy.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Now thou art a tall fellow; and shalt want no sack.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: And, sir, I do honour you (D'ye see) and should wish myself one of your household servants (D'ye see) if I had but a grey beard, d'ye see? Hay, as old master Clack says.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, I have read the business here.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Call it not business, I beseech you, sir. We defy all business.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I marry do we, sir. D'ye see, sir? And a
hay, as old master Clack says.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Gramercy sack. Well, I have read the matter here written by master Clack. And do but bear up in thy humour, I will wait upon thee home. Knock within.hark! they knock to the dresser. I have heard much of this old od-ceited justice Clack: and now I long to see him. 'tis but crossing the country two days and a night's journey. We'll but dine and away presently. Bear up, I say, master talboy.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I will bear up, I warrant you, d'ye see, sir — but here's a grudging still —Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: A great noise within of rude music, laughing, singing, etc.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Here's a wedding with a witness, and a holiday with a hoy. Let us out of the noise, as we love our ears.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes: and here we may pursue our own discourse, and hear one another.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Concerning, Springlove and yourself, mistress Amie.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Well, ladies, my confidence in you, that you are the same that you have protested yourselves to be, hath so far won upon me, that I confess myself well-affected both to the mind and person of that Springlove. And, if he be (As fairly you pretend) a gentleman, I shall easily dispense with fortune.

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: He is, upon our honours.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: How well that high engagement suits your habits.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Our minds and blood are still the same.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I have passed no affiance to the other,
That stole me from my guardian, and the match
He would have forced me to: from which I would
Have fled with any, or without a guide.
Besides, his mind, more clownish than his habit,
Depraved by covetousness and cowardice,
Forced me into a way of misery,
To take relief from beggars.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: From poor us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And then, to offer to marry me under a hedge, as the old couple were today, without book or ring, by the chaplain of the beggar's regiment, your Patrico, only to save charges.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I have not seen the wretch these three hours, whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: He told me, to fetch horse and sit raiment for us; and so to post me hence: but I think it was to leave me on your hands.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He has taken some great distaste sure: for he is damnable jealous.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ay, didst thou mark what a wild look he cast, when Springlove tumbled her, and kissed her on the straw this morning, while the music played to the old wedding-folks?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, and then Springlove, to make him madder, told him, that he would be his proxy, and marry her for him, and lie with her the first night, with a naked cudgel betwixt 'em, and make him a King of beggars.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I saw how it angered him. And I imagined then, and before, that there was more in Springlove, then downright beggar. But though he be never so good a gentleman, he shall observe sit time and distance till we are married.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Matrimony forbid else. (She's taken.) But while we talk of a match towards, we are missed within in the bride-barn among the revel rout.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We have had all the sport they could make us, in the past passages.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: How cautious the old contracted couple were for portion and jointure!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What feoffees, she being an heir of fourscore, (And seven years stone-blind) had, in trust for her estate.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And how carefully he secured all to himself, in case he outlived her, being but seven years older than she. And what pains the lawyer of the rout here, took about it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And then, how solemnly they were joined, and admonished, by our parson under-hedge, to live together in the fear of the lash, and give good example to the younger reprobates, to beg within compass, to escape the jaws of the justice, the clutch of the constable, the hooks of the headborough, and the biting blows of the beadle. And, in so doing, they should defy the devil, and all his works, and after their painful pilgrimage in this life, they should die in the ditch of delight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O but poet Scribble's epithalamium.
To the blind virgin of fourscore,
And the lame bachelor, of more,
how Cupid gave her fies to see,
And Vulcan lent him legs:
How Venus caused their sport to be
Prepared with buttered eggs.
Yet when she shall be seven years wed,
She shall be bold to say,
She has as much her maidenhead,
As on her wedding day.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: So may some wives that were married at sixteen, to lads of one and twenty.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: But at the wedding-feast, when the bride bridled it, and her groom saddled it. There was the sport, in her mumping, and his champing; the crew scrambling; ourselves trembling; then the confusion of noises, in talking, laughing, scolding, singing, howling; with their actions, of snatching, scratching, tousing and lousing themselves, and one another —Enter Springl. Vinc. and Hilliard. but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O, ladies, you have lost as much mirth, as would have filled up a week of holidays.

div.stage: Springlove takes Amy aside, and courts her in a gentile way.

sp.speaker: ●in.
sp.p: I am come about again for the beggar's life now.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are. I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: There is no life but it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: With them there is no grievance or perplexity;
No fear of war, or state disturbances.
No alteration in a commonwealth,
or innovation, shakes a thought of theirs.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Of ours you should say.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Of ours, he means.
We have no fear of lessening our estates;
Nor any grudge with us (Without taxation)
To lend or give, upon command, the whole
Strength of our wealth for public benefit:
While some, that are held rich in their abundance,
(Which is their misery, indeed) will see
Rather a general ruin upon all,
Then give a scruple to prevent the fall.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'Tis only we that live.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I'm glad you are so taken with your calling.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We are no less, I assure you. We find the sweetness of it now.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The mirth, the pleasure, the delights. No ladies live such lives.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Some few, upon necessity, perhaps. But that's not worth gramercy.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: They will never be weary.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Whether we seem to like, or dislike, all's one to them.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We must do something to be taken by, and discovered, we shall never be ourselves, and get home again else.

div.stage: Spr. and Amy come to the rest.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I am yours for ever. Well, ladies, you have missed rare sport; but now the bride has missed you with her half-half eye; and the bridegroom, with the help of his crutches, is drawing her forth for a dance, here, in the opener air. The house is now too hot for 'em. O, here come the chief revellers. The soldier, the courtier, the lawyer, and the poet,
who is master of their revels, before the old couple in state. Attend, and hear him speak, as their inductor.

lg.head: Poet.
lg.l: Here, on this green, like King and Queen,
(For a short truce) we do produce
Our old new-married pair.
Of dish and wallet, and of straw-pallet,
With rags to show, from top to toe,
She is the ancient heir.
He is the lord of bottle-gourd,
Of satchel great, for bread and meat,
And, for small pence, a purse.
To all that give, long may you live
He loudly cries: but who denies
Is sure to have his curse.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Well said field-poet. Phoebus, we see, inspires as well the beggar, as the poet laureate.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And shines as warm under a hedge Bottom, as on the tops of palaces.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I have not done yet. Now this is to incite you to dance.

lg.l: Prepare yourselves, like faëry elves,
Now in a dance to show,
That you approve, the god of love
Has many shafts to's bow:
With golden head, and some of lead,
But that which made these feel,
By subtle craft, was sure a shaft
That headed was with steel.
For they were old; no earth more cold;
Their hearts were flints entire;
Whence the steels stroke did sparks provoke,
That set their bloods on fire.
Now strike up piper; and each lover here
Be blithe, and take his mistress by the goll.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That's no rhyme, poet.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: There's as good poetry in blank verse, as metre.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Come, hay! the dance, the dance. Nay we'll ha' the old couple in, as blind and lame as they are.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What will you so?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Well hobbled bridegroom!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Well groped bride!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hay lusty. Hay holiday.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Set 'em down; set 'em down: they ha' done well.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: A ha! I am lustier than I was 30. years ago.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: And I, than I was threescore passed. A hem, a hemh.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What a night here's towards!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sure they will kill one another.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Each with a fear the tother will live longest.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Poet, thou hast spoken learnedly, and acted bravely. Thou art both poet and actor.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: So has been many famous men. And if here were no worse, we might have a masque, or a comedy presented tonight , in honour of the old couple.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Let us each man try his ability upon some subject now extempore.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Agreed. Give us a theme; and try our action.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I have already thought upon't. I want but actors.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What persons want you? what would you present?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I would present a common wealth; Utopia, with all her branches and consistencies.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'll be Utopia; who must be my branches?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: The country, the city, the court, and the camp. Epitomised and personated by a gentleman, a merchant, a courtier, and a soldier.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: I'll be your soldier. Am not I one? ha!

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: And am not I a fashionable courtier?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: But who the citizen or merchant?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And I your country gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Yet to our moral I must add two persons, divinity and law.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.p: Why la you now. And am not I a lawyer?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: But where's Divinity?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Marry that I know not. One of us might do that, if either knew how to handle it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Where's the old Patrico, our priest, my ghostly father? He'll do it rarely.

sp.speaker: 1 beggar
sp.p: He was telling fortunes e'en now to country wenches. I'll fetch him —

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That Patrico I wonder at: he has told me strange things in clouds.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And me somewhat that I may tell you hereafter.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That you shall be my bride?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I will not tell you now.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Well: but what must our speeches tend to? what must we do one with another?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I would have the country, the city, and the court, be at great variance for superiority. Then would I have divinity and law stretch their wide throats to appease and reconcile them: then would I have the soldier cudgel them all together, and overtop them all. Stay, yet I want another person.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: What must he be?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: A beggar.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Here's enough of us, I think. What must the beggar do?

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: He must, at last, overcome the soldier; and bring them all to beggars-hall. And this, well acted, will be for the honour of our calling.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A scribble! A scribble!

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Come, where's this Patrico, that we may begin?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Alack and welladay, this is no time to play. Our quarter is beset. We are all in the net. Leave off your merry glee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You begin scurvily.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Bing awast, b'ing awast. The choir Cove and the Harmanbeck.

div.stage: Some beggars run over the stage.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: We are beset indeed. What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I hope we shall be taken.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If the good hour be come, welcome by the grace of good fortune.

div.stage: Enter Sentwell, constable, watch. The crew slip away.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Beset the quarter round. Be sure that none escape.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Lord to come with you, blessed master, to a many distressed —

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Hill. Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mer. Good your good worship, duly and truly, etc.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A many counterfeit rogues! So frolic and so lamentable all in a breath? You were acting a play but now: we'll act with you. Incorrigible vagabonds.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Good master, 'tis a holiday with us. An heir was married here today.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Married! Not so I hope. Where is she? 'tis for an heir we seek.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Here she is master — hide yourselves in the straw — the straw. Quickly into the straw —

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What tellest thou me of this? An old blind beggar-woman. We must find a young gentlewoman-heir among you. Where's all the rest of the crew?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Slipped into the barn and the bushes by: but none can scape.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Look you to that, and to these here.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Into the straw, I say.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No, good Springlove. The ladies and we are agreed now to draw stakes, and play this lousy game no further.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We will be taken, and disclose ourselves. You see we shall be forced to it else. The cowardly clerk has don't to save himself.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Do you fear no shame, ladies?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Dost think it a shame to leave begging?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Or that our father will turn us out to it again?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Nay, since you are so resolute, know, that I
myself begin to find this is no course for gentlemen. This lady shall take me off it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Make but your protestations good, and take me yours. And for the gentleman that surprises us, though he has all my uncle's trust, he shall do any thing for me to our advantage.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If, Springlove, thou couldst post now to thy tiring-house, and fetch all our clothes, we might get off most neatly.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A horse and six hours travel would do that.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: You shall be furnished, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: She's scaped, or is invisible. You sir, I take to be the chief rogue of this regiment. Let him be whipped till he brings forth the heir.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: That is but till he stinks, sir. Come, sir, strip, strip.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Unhand him, sir. What heir do you seek, master Sentwell?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: Precious, how did my haste oversee her? O mistress Amy! Could I, or your uncle, justice Clack, a wiser man than I, ever ha' thought to have found you in such company?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Of me, sir, and my company, I have a story to delight you: which on our march towards your house, I will relate to you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p: And thither will I lead you as my guest. But to the law surrender all the rest. I'll make your peace.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We must fare all alike.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have forgiven you. Provided that my niece be safely taken; and so to be brought home. Safely, I say, that is to say, unstained, unblemished, undishonoured; that is to say, with no more faults, criminal, or accusative, than those she carried with her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I believe —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, if we both speak together, how shall we hear one another? you believe her virtue is armour of proof, without your council or your guard; and therefore you left her in the hands of rogues and vagabonds, to make your own peace with me. You have it. Provided, I say (As I said before) that she be safe, that is to say, uncorrupted, undefiled; that is to say — as I said before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mine intent, sir, and my only way —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Nay, if we both speak together, how shall we hear one another? as I said before. Your intent, and your only way, you would ha' said, was to run away with her; and that by her only instigation, to avoid the tie of marriage with master talboy; that is to say, to shun the match, that I had made for her; that is to say, rather to disobey me, than to displease herself. Wherein (Although she did not altogether transgress the law) she did both offend and prejudice me, an instrument; nay, I may say, a pillar thereof. And you, in assisting her, furthering, and conveying her away, did not only infringe the
law, in an unlawful departure from your master, but in a higher point; that is to say, top and top-gallows high. I would ha' found a jury should ha' found it so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But sir, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Must we then both speak together? Have I not born with thee, to speak all thou pleasest in thy defence? Have I not broke mine own rule, which is, to punish before I examine; and so to have the law the surer of my side? And dost thou still persist? Hold your own peace; or, as I am a justice of the Kings, I will unsay what I said before, and set a currat lex at you, sirrah, that shall course you up the heavy hill. O, is your tongue fallen into your leg now? Do not you know I have acquitted you? Provided — as I said before. Go your way in, and see that the gentlemen, who, I think, were got in sack, christened in sack, nursed with sack, and fed up to grey hairs with only sack; see, I say, that they want no sack. My son Oliver (I thank him) has brought me a pair of such guests. Enter Sentwell.
sp.l: O master Sentwell! Good news?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Of beggarly news, the best you have heard.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That is to say, you have found my niece among the beggars. That is to say —

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: True, sir Oliver, I found her —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now if we both speak together, who shall hear one another?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I thought your desire was to be informed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I can inform myself, sir, by your looks. I have taken a hundred examinations i' my days of felons, and other offenders, out of their very countenances; and wrote 'em down verbatim, to
what they would have said. I am sure it has served to hang some of 'em, and whip the rest.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Justice Clack still! He must talk all. His clack must only go.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But to the point. You have found my niece. You have left her at your own house; not only to shift her out of her disguise, but out of her shame, to come nearer me, until I send her pardon.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Most true, sir. But the company she was in —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Again! Do not I know the company? Beggars, rogues, vagabonds, and hedge-birds.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: But do you know whom, or how many we have taken? and how the rest escaped?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A needless knowledge. Why should we take more than herself? Or how could you take those that could escape?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, the old gentlemen within, sent me to wait upon you. Without you (They say) they need not my service.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Tell 'em then, I'll wait on 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
But sir, we have taken with her such beggars, such rogues, such vagabonds, and such hedge-birds (Since you call 'em so) as you never knew, or heard of, though now the country's swarm with 'em under every hedge, as if an innumerable army of 'em were lately disbanded without pay. Hedge-birds said you? Hedge ladybirds, hedge cavaliers, hedge soldier, hedge lawyer, hedge fiddlers, hedge poet, hedge players, and a hedge priest among 'em. Such we have taken for the principals. But to see how the
multitude scaped us; was more sport than pity. How, upon a watchword given, they in the instant vanished by more several ways than there were legs among 'em; how the cripples leaped over pales and hedges; how the blind found their way thorough lakes and ditches; how a doxy flew with two children at her back, and two more, perhaps, in her belly —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A hedge priest have you taken, say you?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Yes, sir, an old Patrico, an ancient prophet, to tell fortunes, and cozen our poor country people of their single money.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, master oldrents, in that he enjoys not your company, begins to doubt of his welcome.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Who led him into that doubt? Ay, or you that brought him hither?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, his own desire, and love to you, brought him hither. I but showed him the way.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You reason fairly. Tell him I come.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray, sir, be pleased to do so: for he says —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, if we both talk together —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Who shall hear one another. Exit. Oliver.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But are there players among the apprehended?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Yes, sir. And they were contriving to act a play among themselves, just as we surprised 'em, and spoiled their sport.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Players! I'll pay them above all the rest.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: You shall do well in that; to put 'em in stock to set up again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Yes, I'll put 'em in stocks, and set 'em up to the whipping-post. They can act justices, can they? I'll act a justice among 'em; that is to say, I will
do justice upon them; that is to say —

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Pray sir, be not severe, they act Kings and emperors, as well as justices. And justice is blind they say: you may therefore be pleased to wink a little. I find that you have merry old gentlemen in your house, that are come far to visit you. I'll undertake that these players, with the help of their poet; in a device which they have already studied, and a pack of clothes which I shall supply 'em with, shall give your guests much content, and move compassion in you towards the poor strolls.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But you know my way of justice (And that's a sure way) is to punish 'em first, and be compassionate afterwards, as I find 'em upon their examination.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: But for your guests sakes, who (I know) do favour and affect the quality of actors very much, permit 'em, sir. It will enlarge your entertainment exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And perhaps save me the expense of a rundlet of sack the while. Well, sir, for that respect, and upon your undertaking that they shall please, I will prorogue my justice on the rogues. And so to my merry gentlemen, whom I will prepare to see their interlude against after supper. But pray, master Sentwell, as you have found my niece, look to her, and see her decently brought home.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: In her own best apparel. But you must prorogue your displeasure to her too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I will do so, until my scarce welcome guests be gone.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Sir, my master sends you word, and plainly,
that without your company, your entertainment stinks. He has commanded me saddle his nags, and away tonight . If you come not at once, twice, thrice, he's gone presently, before supper; he'll find an host at an inn worth a hundred of you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Good friend, I will now satisfy your master, without telling him he has a saucy knave to his man. Exit Clack.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Do you hear, friend, you serve master oldrents.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I could ha' told you that. And the best housekeeper my master is of any gentleman in the county he dwells in; and the best master to a man, as I, the worst of twenty, can say for him, and would be ashamed to say less.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Your name is Randall.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Forgive me! Are you so wise? you are too young to be my godsire. And I hope not old enough to be a witch. How know you, that I am Randall? were you ever at my master's house i' Nottinghamshire, or at Dunghilford, where I was born?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: No. But I have notes to know you by.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I was never twelve mile from thence i' my life, before this journey. God send me within ken of our own kitchen smoke again.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Your master's steward's name is Springlove.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Master Springlove, an't please you. There is not an honester gentleman between this and the head of him. And my heart's with him, where'er he is. Know you him too?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Yes, and your master's daughters too.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: And that they are all from home, your master knows not where.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw. Know you that too?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Yes, and the two young gentlemen that are with 'em, master Vincent, and master Hilliard.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw again. You know 'em all, I think. But know you where they all are?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Even here by, at my own house.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw —

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: And they knowing that your master is here, and master hearty too —

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: And yourself too. They directed me to find you, Randall, and bring you to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw. — why do we not go then?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: But secretly. Not a word to anybody .

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Mum — will you go then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O, master Oldrent's man. Pray let me entreat you into the buttery.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Will you go, master gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed it is my master's desire, and he commanded me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Now, when it's suppertime did he? to fill my belly with thin drink to save his meat? It's the manner in churl's houses. Will you go, master gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Introth my master is so merry with yours within —

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Shite of your master. My master's Steward's a better man. I'll to him, at this gentleman's house, and all the rest. Whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Randall, you forget.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Mum again then. Why would you not go then? Exit sent. and Rand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The man's as mad as his master. The strangest strangers that ever came to our house.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Well, Martin, for confessing thy fault, and the means thou madest whereby she is taken, I am friends with thee. But I shall never look upon her, or thee — but with grief of mind, however I bear it outwardly. O —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You bear it very manfully, methinks .

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ay, you think so, and I know so — but what I feel, I feel. Would one of us two had never both seen one another. — o —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You speak very good sense, sir. But does my master continue his merry humour with the old gentlemen within.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Yes. Justice Clack's clack goes as merrily as any.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well said, sir. Now you speak merrily too. But I could say somewhat that would still him. And for your comfort, I'll tell you. Mistress Amie is fallen in love with one of the beggars.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Then have I nothing else to do, but to laugh at thee as long as I live. Ha ha ha — to let a beggar cozen thee of her. Ha ha ha. A beggar! I shall die merrily yet. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A hay boys, a hay. This is right; that is to say, as I would have it; that is to say —

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: A beggar. Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A hay boys, a hay. They are as merry without, as we were within. A hay, master oldrents, and master hearty! The virtue of your company turns all to mirth and melody, with a hay trololly lolly lolly. Is't not so, master hearty?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why thus it should be: how was I deceived! Now I see you are a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He was never so before. If it be a lightning before death, the best is, I am his heir.

sp.speaker: Tal. Mar.
sp.p: Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Again, boys, again; that is to say, a hay boys, ah hay —

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: What is the motive of your mirth, nephew Martin? Let us laugh with you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Was that spoke like my friend, hearty? Lack we motives to laugh? Are not all things, any thing, every thing to be laughed at? And if nothing were to be seen, felt, heard, or understood, we would laugh at it too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You take the loss of your mistress merrily, master talboy.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: More merrily than you will take the finding of her. Ha ha ha — a beggar! Ha ha ha —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Can I be sad to find her, think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He thinks you will be displeased with her, and chide her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
You are deceived, master talboy; you are wide, master talboy; above half your length, master talboy. Law and justice shall sleep, and mirth and good fellowship ride a circuit here tonight . A hay, master oldrents, a hay master hearty, and a hay son Oliver, and a hay nephew talboy, that should ha' been, and a hay, my clerk Martin, and a hay for
the players. When come they? Son Oliver, see for master Sentwell, that is no readier with his new company.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Players! Let us go see too. I never saw any players. Exit Talb. Mar.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: This is the first fit that ever he had of this disease. And if it be his last, I say, as I said before. I am his heir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: But is there a play to be expected, and acted by beggars?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That is to say, by vagabonds; that is to say, by strolling players. They are upon their purgation. If they can present any thing to please you, they may escape the law; that is (A hay) if not, tomorrow , gentlemen, shall be acted, abuses stripped and whipped, among 'em; with a hay, master hearty, you are not merry. Enter Sentwell.and a hay master Sentwell, where are your dramatis personae; your prologus, and your actus primus, ha? Have they given you the slip, for fear of the whip? A hay.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A word aside, an't please you. —

div.stage: Sentwell takes Clack aside, and gives him a paper.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I have not known a man in such a humour.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: And of his own finding! He stole it, indeed, out of his own bottles, rather than be robbed of his liquor. Miser's use to tipple themselves so.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: He does so outdo us, that we look like stayed men again, hearty; fine sober things.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: But how long will it last? He'll hang himself tomorrow, for the cost we have put him to.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
I love a miser's feast dear. To see how
thin and scattering the dishes stood, as if they feared quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: And how the bottles, to scape breaking one another, were brought up by one at once!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How one of the serving-men, untrained to wait, spilt the white-broth!

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: And another, stumbling at the threshold, tumbled in his dish of rouncivals before him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: And most suitable to the niggardliness of his feast, we shall now have an entertainment, or play, presented by beggars.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Send 'em in, master Sentwell. Exit sent.sat gentlemen, the players are ready to enter. And here's a bill of their plays. You may take your choice.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Are they ready for them all in the same clothes? Read 'em, good hearty.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: First, here's the two lost daughters.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Put me not in mind of the two lost daughters, I prithee. What's the next?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The vagrant steward.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Nor of a vagrant steward. Sure some abuse is meant me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The old squire and the fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: That comes nearer me. Away with it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The beggar's prophecy.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: All these titles may serve to one play, of a story that I know too well. I'll see none of them.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Then here's the merry beggars.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Ay, that; and let 'em begin.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: The players are coming in: and mistress Amie and your man Martin, are to be actors among 'em.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A hay then for that too. Some merry device sure. A flourish of shalms.hark! the beggar's hoboys. Now they begin.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: See, a most solemn prologue.

div.l: To knight, to squire, and to the gentiles here,
We wish our play may with content appear.
We promise you no dainty wit of court,
Nor city pageantry, nor country sport:
But a plain piece of action, short and sweet;
In story true. You'll know it when you see't.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: True storeys and true jests do seldom thrive on stages.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: They are best to please you with this though, or a hay with a whip for them tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Nay, rather than they shall suffer, I will be pleased, let 'em play their worst.

div.stage: A flourish. enter Patrico. With lawyer habited like oldrents.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: That offered you a doxy in the barn.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Your children's fortunes I have told,
That they shall beg ere they be old.
And will you have a reason why?
'Tis justice in their destiny. —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Justice, ha! Are you meddling with justices already?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Your grandfather, by crafty wile
Of bargaining, did much beguile
A thriftless heir of half the lands
That are descended to your hands.
And, then, by law, not equity,
Forced him and his posterity
To woe and shameful beggary.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.p: That was no fault of mine, nor of my children.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: But our forefather's debts and crimes,
Although forborn till future times,
Are not so paid. But what needs more,
I wish you happy in your store. Exit.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Dost note this, hearty?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: You said you would be pleased, let 'em play their worst.

div.stage: Lawyer walks sadly, beats his breast, etc. To him enter soldier like hearty, and seems to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: It begins my story, and by the same fortune-teller that told me my daughter's fortunes; almost in the same words. I know him now. And he speaks in the play to one that personates me, as near, as they can set him forth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How like you it, sir? You seem displeased. Shall they be whipped yet? A hay, if you say the word.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O, by no means, sir; I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sad for the words of a base fortune-teller? Believe him! Hang him. I'll trust none of 'em. They have all whims, and double double meanings in all they say.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Whom does he talk or look like, now?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: It is no matter whom. You are pleased, you say.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Have you no sack i'th house? am not I here? And never without a merry old song?
sp.l: Old sack, and old songs, and a merry old crew,
Will fright away cares when the ground looks blue.
And can you think on Gipsy fortune-tellers?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: I'll think as little of 'em as I can.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Will you abroad then? But here comes your steward.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Bless me! Is not that Springlove?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Is that you, that talks to him, or that coxcomb I, do you think? Pray let 'em play their play: the justice will not hinder 'em, you see; he's asleep.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Here are the keys of all my charge, sir. And
My humble suit is, that you will be pleased
To let me walk upon my known occasions, this summer.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Fie! Canst not yet leave off those vagancies?
But I will strive no more to alter nature.
I will not hinder thee, nor bid thee go.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My own very words at his departure.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: No matter. Pray attend.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Come, friend, I'll take your council.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I've striven with myself to alter nature in me,
For my good master's sake; but all in vain;
For beggars, cuckoo-like, fly out again,
In their own notes and season.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Our father's sadness will not suffer us to live in's house.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And we must have a progress.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Th' assurance of your love's hath engaged us

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: To wait on you in any course.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Suppose we'll go a-begging .

sp.speaker: Vin. Hil.
sp.l: We are for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: And that must be your course, and suddenly,
To cure your father's sadness; who is told
It is your destiny: which you may quit,
By making it a trick of youth and wit.
I'll set you in the way.

sp.speaker: All 4.
sp.l: But how? But how?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My daughters and their sweethearts too. I see
The scope of their design; and the whole drift
Of all their action now, with joy and comfort.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: But take no notice yet. See a Whim more of it. But the mad rogue that acted me, I must make drunk anon.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Now! are you all resolved?

sp.speaker: All 4.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You beg to absolve your fortune, not for need.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I must commend their act in that. Praythee let's call 'em, and end the matter here. The purpose of their play, is but to work my friendship, or their peace with me; and they have it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: But see a little more, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: My man Randall too! Has he a part with 'em?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: They were well set a work, when they made me a player. What is that I must say? And how must I act now? Oh! that I must be steward for the beggars in master Steward's absence; and tell my master, he's gone to measure land for him to purchase.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: You sir. Leave the work you can do no better (I can forbear no longer) and call the actors back again to me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: With all my heart. And glad my part is so soon done. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Since you will then break off our flay:
Something in earnest I must say;
But let affected rhyming go.
I'll be no more a Patrico.
My name is wrought-on — start not. But (If you
Desire to hear what's worth your best attention,
More privately) you may draw nearer me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Hear no more fortunes.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: You shall give me leave.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I am grandson to that unhappy wrought-on,
Whom your grandfather, craftily, wrought out
Of his estate. By which, all his posterity
Were, since, exposed to beggary. I do not charge
You, with the least offence in this. But, now,
Come nearer me: for I must whisper to you.

div.l: I had a sister, who among the race
Of beggars, was the fairest. Fair she was
In gentle blood, and gesture to her beauty;
Which could not be so clouded with base clothing,
But she attracted love from worthy persons;
Which (For her meanness) they expressed in pity,
For the most part. But some assaulted her
With amorous, though loose desires; which she
Had virtue to withstand. Only one gentleman
(Whether it were by her affection, or
his fate, to send his blood a-begging with her,
I question not) by her, in heat of youth,
Did get a son, who now must call you father.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You. Attend me, sir. Your bounty, then,
Disposed your purse to her; in which, besides
Much money (I conceive by your neglect)
Was thrown this holy relic. Do you know it?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: The Agnus dei that my mother gave me
Upon her deathbed! O the loss of it
Was my sore grief: and, now, with joy, it is
Restored by miracle! Does your sister live?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No, sir. She died within a few days after
Her son was born; and left him to my care;
On whom, ay, to this day, have had an eye,
In all his wanderings.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Then the young man lives!

div.stage: Enter Springlove. Vincent. Hilliard. Rachell. Meriel.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Here with the rest of your fair children, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My joy begins to be too great within me!
My blessing, and a welcome to you all.
Be one another's, and you all are mine.

sp.speaker: Vin. Hil.
sp.l: We are agreed on that.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Long since. We only stood till you shook off your sadness.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For which we were fain to go a-begging , sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Now I can read the justice of my fate, and yours —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ha! justice? Are they handling of justice?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: But more applaud great providence in both.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Are they jeering of justices? I watched for that.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I so methought . No, sir. The play is done.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: See, sir, your niece presented to you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What, with a speech by one of the players?
Speak, sir: and be not daunted. I am favourable.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Then, by your favour, sir, this maiden is my wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sure you are out of your part. That is to say, you must begin again.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: She's mine by solemn contract, sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You will not tell me that. Are not you my niece?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I dare not, sir, deny't, we are contracted.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, if we both speak together, how shall we hear one another?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I must disprove the contract.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: That is my part to speak.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: None can disprove it. I am witness to it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, if we all speak — as I said before.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Hear me for all then. Here are no beggars (You are but one, patrico) no rogues, nor players: but a select company, to fill this house with mirth. These are my daughters; these their husbands; and this that shall marry your niece, a gentleman, my son. I will instantly estate him in a thousand pound a year to entertain his wife; and to their heirs for ever. Do you hear me now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now I do hear you. And I must hear you. That is to say, it is a match. That is to say — as I said before.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: And must I hear it too — oh —

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Yes, though you whine your eyes out.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Nephew Martin, still the child with a suckbottle of sack. Peace, lamb; and I'll find a wife for thee.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Now, Patrico, if you can quit your function,
To live a moderate gentleman, I'll give you
A competent annuity for your life.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I'll be, withal, your faithful beadsman; and spend my whole life in prayers for you and yours.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And now, clerk Martin, give all the beggars my free pass, without all manner of correction? that is to say, with a hay get 'em gone.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Are not you the gentleman, that challenged me in right of your friend here?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Your inspection's good, sir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And you the gentleman (I take it) that would have made beggar-sport with us, two at once.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For twelve pence a piece, sir.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I hope we all are friends.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Now, on my duty, sir, I'll beg no more, but your continual love, and daily blessing.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Except it be at court, boy; where if ever I come, it shall be to beg the next fool-royal's place that falls.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: A begging epilogue yet would not be,
Methinks , improper to this comedy.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Though we are, now, no beggars of the crew,
We count it not a shame to beg of you.
The justice, here, has given his pass free
To all the rest, unpunished; only we
Are under censure, till we do obtain
Your suffrages, that we may beg again;
And often, in the course, we took today,
Which was intended, for your mirth, a play;
Not without action, and a little wit,
Therefore we beg your pass for us and it.
